questions.text: Which of the following options gives Real number:
options: Both option A and option C
questions.solution:
Option A: $$\sqrt{24\% \text{ of } 6400 + 22} = \sqrt{1536+22} = \sqrt{1558}$$ (Real number).
Option B: $$\sqrt{2\times48-10^{2}} = \sqrt{96-100} = \sqrt{-4}$$ (Not real number).
Option C: $$\sqrt{22^{2}+3^{3}-57} = \sqrt{484+27-57} = \sqrt{454}$$ (Real number).
Hence, option D is correct.

questions.text:
Which of the following is/are correct:
I: $$x^{2}=29^{2}+(22\% \text{ of } 200)-30^{2}$$ (The value of 'x' in this equation is not real number)
II: $$\sqrt{26\% \text{ of } 2500-5^{2}}$$ gives a positive integer.
III: $$(8^{3}+5^{2}+63-10^{3})$$ gives a negative integer.
questions.solution:
I: $$x^{2}=841+44-900 = -15$$ 
 $$x=\sqrt{-15}$$ (Not real number). Correct.
II: $$\sqrt{650-25} = \sqrt{625} = 25$$ (Positive integer). Correct.
III: $$512+25+63-1000 = -400$$ (Negative integer). Correct.
Hence, option D is correct.

questions.text: Product of -2 and 0 gives
questions.solution:
If we multiply 0 with any number it gives 0 which is a whole number.
Hence, option C is correct.

questions.text:
Statement I: $$x/2=22\times23+94-25^{2}+5^{2}$$
Statement II: $$y=44\% \text{ of } 300+54-20$$
The value of 'x' from statement I and 'y' from statement II are collectively known as
questions.solution:
Statement I: $$x/2=506+94-625+25 
 x/2=0 
 x=0$$
Statement II: $$y=132+54-20 
 y=166$$
x is zero and y is a positive integer, so they collectively known as whole number.
Hence, option A is correct.

questions.text:
Which of the given options can give possible value of $$(A\times B\times C)$$
$$A=$$ Whole number
$$B=$$ Negative integer
$$C=$$ Positive integer
questions.solution:
Product of a whole number (if 0), negative integer and positive integer always gives 0.
Product of a whole number (if not zero), negative integer and positive integer always gives negative integer.
(which is given in option D)
Hence, option E is correct.

questions.text:
Find the nature of the given statements:
I: $$x=p/q$$ (Here, 'p' and 'q' are integer)
II: $$Y=p/q$$ (Here, 'p' and 'q' are non-integer)
options: X is rational and Y is irrational.
X is irrational and Y is rational.
X and Y both are rational.
X and Y both are irrational.
questions.solution:
$$p/q$$ (Here, 'p' and 'q' are integer) -> X is a rational number.
$$p/q$$ (Here, 'p' and 'q' are non-integer) -> Y is an irrational number.
Hence, option A is correct.

questions.text:
Which of the following is/are correct:
I: $$A+B=C$$
II: $$A-B=D$$
Here, A and B are Irrational and rational number respectively.
options: Both C and D are rational
Both C and D are irrational
C is rational and D is irrational
C is irrational and D is rational
questions.solution:
Irrational number + rational number = Irrational (Always)
Irrational number - rational number = Irrational (Always)
Hence, option B is correct.

questions.text:
If $$P=$$ Irrational number, $$Q=$$ Rational number, then the product of P and Q is equal to $$A/B$$.
Which of the following options is correct for 'A' and 'B':
options: Both A and B are integer.
Both A and B are non-integer.
questions.solution:
Irrational number $$\times$$ Rational number = Irrational number
Irrational number $$=A/B$$
Here, Both A and B are non-integer.
Hence, option B is correct.

questions.text:
Which of the following options is correct for the value of A from the given equation.
$$3A^{3}=26\% \text{ of } 200+16\times3+(25\% \text{ of } 800)$$

Which of the following statement is/are possibly true:
I: If A and B both are irrational, then the product of A and B can be equal to 4.
II: If A and B both are irrational, then the product of A and B can be equal to $$\sqrt{6}$$.
questions.solution:
Irrational number $$\times$$ Irrational number = Either rational or irrational number
I: Product can be 4 (Rational). True (e.g., $$\sqrt{8} \times \sqrt{2} = 4$$).
II: Product can be $$\sqrt{6}$$ (Irrational). True (e.g., $$\sqrt{2} \times \sqrt{3} = \sqrt{6}$$).
Hence, option C is correct.

questions.text:
Which of the following can be false, if A and B are irrational number:
I: $$A-B=\sqrt{8-\sqrt{7}}$$
II: $$A-B=$$ whole number
questions.solution:
Irrational number - Irrational number = Either rational or irrational.
So, I is true (Irrational result).
In II: If $$A=\sqrt{2}$$, $$B=\sqrt{2}$$, then $$A-B=0$$ (whole number). So II is true.
Since both can be true, neither is necessarily false.
Hence, option C is correct.

questions.text: If A is odd number and $$A+B=144$$, then the nature of B is
questions.solution:
$$\text{odd} + \text{odd} = \text{even}$$
If A is odd and sum is even (144), then B should be odd.
Hence, option A is correct.

questions.text:
Find the possible value of D. (A, B, D are integers)
I: $$A+B=64$$
II: $$B+D=45$$
options: All option A, B and C can be the possible value
questions.solution:
I: $$A+B=64$$ (Even sum -> A and B same parity)
II: $$B+D=45$$ (Odd sum -> B and D opposite parity)
If B is odd, D is even.
If B is even, D is odd.
Since D *can* be odd, all the given options (11, 47, 9) are possible values.
Hence, option D is correct.

questions.text:
Product of A and B is C, If the nature of A, B and C is same, then find the Possible value of C.
(Nature = Either odd or even)
questions.solution:
$$\text{odd} \times \text{odd} = \text{odd}$$ (A, B, C all odd). Possible. C can be 21 or 11.
$$\text{even} \times \text{even} = \text{even}$$ (A, B, C all even). Possible. C can be even (10).
Hence, option D is right.

questions.text: If $$P\times Q=$$ Even number and $$P\times R=$$ Even number, then find the possible value of Q from the given options: (R is an integer but not odd number, $$R>0$$)
questions.solution:
R is an even number. $$P \times R = \text{Even}$$ is always true for integer P.
$$P \times Q = \text{Even}$$. 
If P is even, Q can be odd or even.
If P is odd, Q must be even.
Since P is unknown, Q can potentially be odd or even (11 or 12).
Hence, option D is correct.

questions.text: If $$A-B=63$$, then value of A and B is ______ and ______ number respectively.
questions.solution:
$$\text{Odd} - \text{even} = \text{odd}$$
$$\text{Even} - \text{odd} = \text{odd}$$
Since difference is odd (63), one number must be odd and the other even.
Hence, option E is correct.

questions.text:
If P and Q both are odd numbers, R and S both are even numbers, then find the possible value of $$A+B$$
Note: $$P-Q=A$$, $$R-S=B$$
questions.solution:
$$\text{Odd} - \text{odd} = \text{even}$$ (So A is even)
$$\text{even} - \text{even} = \text{even}$$ (So B is even)
$$A+B = \text{even} + \text{even} = \text{even}$$
All options are even numbers.
Hence, option E is correct.

questions.text: If $$P\times Q=$$ Even number and Q is a prime number ($$Q>2$$), then find the value of P.
questions.solution:
$$Q>2$$ and Q is prime number, means $$Q=\text{odd}$$
$$\text{even} \times \text{odd} = \text{even}$$
So, P is an even number.
Hence, option D is correct.

questions.text: If $$P+Q=$$ odd number and P is prime number, then find the possible value of Q.
options: Option A, B, C and D
questions.solution:
$$P+Q=\text{Odd}$$. One is even, one is odd.
P is a prime number.
If $$P=2$$ (even), $$Q=\text{odd}$$. (7, 11 possible)
If $$P=\text{odd}$$ (prime > 2), $$Q=\text{even}$$. (2, 10 possible)
Hence, option E is correct.

questions.text: If P is prime number and $$P+Q=18$$, the number of factors of Q is more than 2, then find the value of Q. ($$P<Q$$)
questions.solution:
Q has more than 2 factors, means Q is a composite number. $$P<Q$$.
Pairs for $$P+Q=18$$:
If $$P=2$$, $$Q=16$$ (Composite). Valid.
If $$P=3$$, $$Q=15$$ (Composite). Valid.
If $$P=5$$, $$Q=13$$ (Prime). Invalid.
If $$P=7$$, $$Q=11$$ (Prime). Invalid.
Hence, Value of Q is either 15 or 16.
So, option D is correct.
